audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker from "Navara Media" introducing Owen Jones. A second male speaker joins, and they discuss being out in "Co-Idun" and "pounding those streets, knocking on those...no door unknocked", praising a phenomenal army. Their tone is casual and enthusiastic. A snippet of music plays, adding to a sense of excitement.

The audio starts with a male speaker stating that Corby had a 150-vote majority for Gavin Barwell, whom he identifies as a Tory housing minister. He speaks in a fairly casual tone, asserting that Tories have a good record on housing but that there are "too many affordable homes". He mentions a "huge army out". He describes the crowd as young and diverse. The speaker suggests that the crowd may have experienced the "sharp end" of Barwell's policies, and that it swept through the constituency, contrasting the Tory's money with the army's people on the ground.

The clip starts with a male speaker describing "a racket of vested interests" followed by acknowledgment of receiving a flyer from a relief worker. A female speaker then joins, dismissing the volunteer as a robot and highlighting the "huge army" of campaigners across the country, though expressing burnout. She notes the novelty of many volunteers, young people in their twenties who are campaigning for the first time. The clip closes with a male voice saying "amazing." Background noise consistent throughout the clip suggests an outdoor environment with sounds of general commotion.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker starting an interview and referring to a campaign. The male speaker has a slightly questioning tone, asking, "Have you been pleasantly surprised?" A second male speaker answers, noting he supported the campaign from the beginning, but expressing doubt. He acknowledges the angry comments that might point this out. His tone then shifts to a more positive assessment of the campaign, describing it as having proven him wrong. He refers to an implosion, and says the campaign is offering a vision, mentioning education, health, housing, and jobs. The speaker summarizes the message as asking those at the top to spread their money and allow a living wage to happen. The speaker continues, implying a worry people's minds were made up, preventing the message from being heard.

The clip opens with a male speaker discussing being proven decisively wrong, expressing relief that "a lot of people have just changed their minds and have been inspired," contrary to his fear of poor polling numbers in the early twenties. He emphasizes the power of a "grassroots movement and inspiring vision". Another male speaker adds that people are more receptive to socialism than previously believed, then humorously exclaims, "They bloody love it!" Following this, the first male speaker requests a bit of "clairvoyance". Throughout this exchange, a consistent, yet quiet ambient sound, is present.

The audio features a single male speaker asking for predictions about newspaper headlines for the upcoming election day. His tone is conversational and inquisitive. His request specifically mentions "The Sun," "Daily Mail," and "The Guardian." Sounds of general public ambiance are heard in the background, suggesting an interview taking place in a public location.

The clip starts with one male speaker. He asks what the headline will be in The Sun, then another male speaker says: "Corbyn will nationalize your mother," and, "He will force everyone to change their first name to Osama Bin Laden." Then the first male speaker asks what the headline will be in The Daily Mail, and the second male speaker says: "Every street in Britain will have to be renamed Vladimir Lenin is welcome," and, "We should all wear Soviet berets." The audio takes place outdoors in public as background ambient noise of people talking can be heard.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker talking about "the Guardian," clarifying it "is a liberal newspaper, not a socialist newspaper." He mentions some of the writers the Guardian has on the left. In the background, there is ambient noise with a moderate and consistent rhythm, creating a setting that is potentially outdoors and public.

The audio clip opens with speech from a male voice discussing the Guardian's story about Labour, saying "wholeheartedly about Labour in this election," and advocating to "vote Labour". This male voice then discusses election polls with another male voice. The first male voice hopes for "solid... Labour's done something good." The clip concludes with the mention that the content is being released on election day, amidst general background sounds that are difficult to make out.

The clip starts with a man in a moderately agitated tone suggesting they shouldn't waste the opportunity to speak with Owen Jones. He asks, "What should people be doing this afternoon?". Owen Jones responds with pleading in his voice, requesting viewers look at his "puppy dog pleading eyes." He emphasizes the importance of doing "every last thing you can do" to get people to vote for Labour, finishing with the question, "then when?" Background noises suggest an outdoor environment with a crowd and general ambient chatter.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker passionately advocating for a labor party, promising "an inspiring vision" and improvements in housing, jobs, poverty reduction, education, and social care. He urges listeners to "drag" people to the polling station and highlights the support from younger voters, non-voters, and women. Simultaneously, indistinct background sounds create an ambient environment. This transitions into speech from another male.

The audio clip begins with someone describing how older Tories believe young people are lazy and won't vote, urging them to prove this wrong. They emphasize the importance of voting for change and influencing others to do the same, speaking with urgency. Then, someone thanks the speaker and mentions that the clip will be watched on Facebook. Sounds of background chatter and what seems like general conversation suggest the setting of the clip is a public space, such as a rally or a gathering.

The clip begins with a male speaker who is excited and enthusiastic, providing a political message and ideas for how to participate in political action. He suggests messaging people who haven't been talked to about politics recently, and visiting a website to find areas that need help. Another male speaker then speaks, sharing that the process of political participation is easy, and highlighting the fact that new people will be paired with experienced participants. He also says that he believes it will "change the world." The first speaker comes back and says that voting is Friday if you vote conservative.

The audio clip begins with speech, featuring a male speaker who encourages listeners by saying, "You've done everything you can do for socialism today," suggesting listeners to "sit back, relax" and tune into the "Navara's all night live election coverage." The tone is positive and promotional. Following the speech, a short musical interlude plays. The genre seems ambient with a slightly unsettling mood.  Afterward, a distinct sound effect is heard.
